case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad v. assessee-company

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 819 of 1966 filed by Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 819 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 30, 1964 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Referred No. 6 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 30, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in case Referred No. 6 of 1963.

facts.text: Respondent is a private limited company owning cinema house Sree Rama Talkies at Bobbili.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent  hereinafter referred to as the  assessee- companypany  is a private limited companypany owning a cinema house called Sree Rama Talkies, at Bobbili.

facts.text: At Board of Directors meeting on September 9, 1955, resolved to authorize Managing Director, Raja of Bobbili, to negotiate sale of entire concern to Zamindar of Chikkavaram for Rs. 1,20,000.

anchor.surface_text: At a meeting of its Board of Directors held on September 9, 1955, it was resolved that the Managing Director, the Raja of Bobbili may be authorised to negotiate with the Zamindar of Chikkavaram or his numberinee for the sale of the entire companycern with all its equipment and machinery, fittings etc. for a companysideration of Rs. 1,20,000/-

facts.text: Agreement concluded and confirmed by assessee-company at extra-ordinary general body meeting on October 4, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: An agreement was companycluded to effect a saLe and this was companyfirmed by the assessee-company at an extra-ordinary general body meeting held on October 4, 1955.

facts.text: Exchange deed executed on February 21, 1956; assessee received 5 tax-free cumulative preference shares in Sri Rama Sugar and Industries Ltd., Bobbili, face value Rs. 1,20,000 held by Zamindar and Zamindarini of Chikkavaram.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant thereto a deed called the exchange deed was brought into existence on February 21, 1956 and the companysideration was received by the assessee- S78 companypany in the shape of transfer of 5 tax-free cumulative preference shares in Sri Rama Sugar and Industries Ltd., Bobbili. of the face value of Rs. 1,20,000/- held by the Zamindar and Zamindarini of Chikkavaram.

facts.text: Separate valuation: immovable property Rs. 60,000; movables etc. and goodwill Rs. 60,000.

anchor.surface_text: Separate valuation was given for the immovable property and for the movables etc. and goodwill, each being valued at Rs. 60,000/-

facts.text: For assessment year 1956-57, assessee submitted return showing Rs. 9,823 as profits from transaction.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1956-57, the assessee-company submitted a return of income showing a sum of Rs. 9,823/- as profits derived from the transaction.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer found value realised exceeded written down value by Rs. 43,568 and computed profits under s.10(2)(vii) IT Act 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer found that the value realised exceeded the written down value by Rs. 43,568/- and accordingly companyputed the profits under S. 10 2  vii  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 and included the amount in the taxable income of the assessee-company.

facts.text: ITO order confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, except allowing Rs. 5,000 for goodwill.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income-tax Officer was companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in appeal and by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal except for allowing a sum of Rs. 5,0001- as representing the companyt of the goodwill.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal stated case under s.66(2) IT Act 1922 as directed by High Court on questions about whether transaction is sale under s.10(2)(vii) and consideration market value Rs.95/share or face value.

anchor.surface_text: As directed by the High Court, the Appellate Tribunal stated a case under s. 66 2  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 on the following question of law Whether the transaction dated 21-2-1956 amounts to a sale within the purview of the second proviso to section 10 2   vii  of the Indian Incometax Act alternatively, Whether the companysideration for the sale is number the market value of the shares as on the date of the transaction, namely, Rs. 95/- per share, but the face value of the shares.

facts.text: High Court answered questions in favour of assessee-company against Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the reference the High Court answered the question in favour of the assessee-company and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal brought by special leave on behalf of Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by special leave, on behalf of the Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad from the judgement of the Andhra Pradesh High Court dated October 30, 1964 in a case Referred No. 6 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the companysideration for the sale is number the market value of the shares as on the date of the transaction, namely, Rs. 95/- per share, but the face value of the shares.

facts.text: Court held transaction is exchange, not sale, so s.10(2)(vii) not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the Income-tax authorities were number entitled to treat the transaction dated February 21, 1956 as a sale and to apply the provisions of s. 10 2   vii  of the Income- tax Act.

arguments.claim: Exchange is mutual transfer of ownership of things neither or both being money per s.118 TPA

anchor.surface_text: Section 118 of the Transfer of Property Act defines exchange as follows When two persons mutually transfer the ownership of one thing for the ownership of another, neither thing, or both things being money only, the transaction is called an exchange.

arguments.claim: Operative part of document shows exchange of properties in Sch.I for shares in Sch.II, no money price

arguments.claim: Without fraud or bad faith, tax per legal form and document construction, not substance

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any suggestion of bad faith or fraud the true principle is that the taxing statute has to be applied in accordance with the legal rights of the parties to the transaction... liability to tax depends upon the meaning and content of the language used

holdings.text: In essence the transaction is one of exchange and there was no sale of the properties described in Sch. I for any money consideration.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Operative part of exchange deed effects mutual transfer of cinema assets for shares without money price; applies definitions of sale (TPA s.54 requiring money price, SOGA s.2(10),4) and exchange (TPA s.118).

holdings.text: It follows therefore that the Income-tax authorities were not entitled to treat the transaction dated February 21, 1956 as a sale and to apply the provisions of s. 10(2)(vii) of the Income-tax Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No sale as lacking money consideration, so second proviso to s.10(2)(vii) IT Act 1922 on profits from excess sale price over written down value does not apply.

holdings.text: neither the recital in the preamble nor the resolution of the Board of Directors dated September 9, 1955 will control the language of the operative portion of the document or its legal effect. There is no ambiguity in the construction of the operative part.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary rules of construction: operative part prevails over preamble recitals and prior resolutions.

holdings.text: In the absence of any suggestion of bad faith or fraud the true principle is that the taxing statute has to be applied in accordance with the legal rights of the parties to the transaction. When the transaction is embodied in a document the liability to tax depends upon the meaning and content of the language used in accordance with the ordinary rules of construction.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any suggestion of bad faith or fraud the true principle is that the taxing statute has to be applied in accordance with the legal rights of the parties to the transaction. When the transaction is embodied

holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation of fraud or bad faith; follows precedents (Bank of Chettinad Ltd. v. CIT, Duke of Westminster) that tax applies to legal form and rights per document, not substance.

anchor.surface_text: Madam Pillai v. Badrakali Ammal 1 . Section 4 of the Sale of Goods Act reads as follows A companytract of sale of goods is a companytract whereby the seller transfers or agrees to transfer the property in goods to the buyer for a price. There may be a companytract of sale between one part-owner and another.

precedents.cited_proposition: the word price is used in the same sense in section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act as in s. 4 of the Sale of Goods Act, 1930

precedents.citation: Bank of Chettinad Ltd. v. C.I.T. Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Bank of Chettinad Ltd. v. C.I.T. Madras 1 , it was pointed out by the Judicial Committee that the doctrine that in revenue cases the substance of the matter may be regarded as distinguished from the strict legal position, is erroneous. If a person sought to be taxed companyes within the letter of the law he must be taxed, however great the hardship may appear to the judicial mind to be.

precedents.case_name: Bank of Chettinad Ltd. v. C.I.T. Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: in revenue cases the substance of the matter may not be regarded as distinguished from the strict legal position; tax if within letter of law, free if not
precedents.cited_holding: the doctrine that in revenue cases the substance of the matter may be regarded as distinguished from the strict legal position, is erroneous

anchor.surface_text: Duke of Westminsters cave 1  deeds of companyenant had been executed by the Duke in favour of employees in such amounts that the companyenantees, if remaining in the Dukes service, would receive respectively sums equivalent to their wages and salaries. If they left the services of the Duke the payments would still have been due, but it was in nearly all instances explained to the employee that so long as the service companytinued, while the deed did number prevent his claiming ordinary wages in addition, it was expected that he would number do so.

precedents.cited_proposition: payments under deed are not to be treated as salary despite substance argument; regard legal rights over form labels
precedents.cited_holding: to regard the payments under the deed as in effect payments of salary would be to treat a transaction of one legal character as if it were a transaction of a different legal character

precedents.citation: Secretary of State in Council of India v. Scoble, 1903 C. 299 4 T.C. 618

anchor.surface_text: Secretary of State in Council of India v. Scoble,  1903  C. 299  4 T.C. 618  that and numbermore. If, on the other hand, the doctrine means that you may brush aside deeds, disregard the legal rights and liabilities arising under a companytract between parties, and decide the question of taxability or number-taxability upon the footing of the rights and liabilities of the parties being different from what in law they are, then I entirely dissent from such a, doctrine.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State in Council of India v. Scoble
precedents.cited_proposition: having once ascertained the legal rights of the parties you may disregard mere nomenclature and decide taxability in accordance with the legal rights

precedents.citation: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Wesleyan and General Assurance Society 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Wesleyan and General Assurance Society 1  Viscount Simon expressed the principle as follows It may be well to repeat two propositions which are well established in the application of the law relating to Income Tax. First, the name given to a transaction by the parties companycerned does number necessarily decide the nature of the transaction.

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Wesleyan and General Assurance Society
precedents.cited_proposition: the name given to a transaction by the parties concerned does not necessarily decide the nature of the transaction; question is real character of the payment
precedents.cited_holding: the name given to a transaction by the parties concerned does not necessarily decide the nature of the transaction. To call a payment a loan if it is really an annuity does not assist the tax-payer
